doc.after: The severe lack of burial space in London meant that graves would be frequently reused in London's burial grounds, and the difficulty of digging without disturbing existing graves led to bodies often simply being stacked on top of each other to fit the available space and covered with a layer of earth.[14] Differing numbers of parishioners in each parish led to burial grounds being used at different rates, and by the mid-19th century, the ground level of the St Botolph's Aldersgate churchyard was 6 feet (1.8Â m) above that of the Christ Church Greyfriars burial ground, and 4 feet (1.2Â m) above that of the St Leonard, Foster Lane, burial ground.[15]
